I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Vanuatu requested technical assistance (TA) to expand access to 
financial services for its rural population with Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing. This 
assistance1  is  consistent  with  the  Government’s  Priorities  and  Action  Agenda,2  which 
encourages  economic  growth,  addresses  low  private  sector  investment,  and  reduces 
unemployment. It is also consistent with ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005–2009, and is included in 
the country strategy and program update 2006–2009.3 ADB’s strategy for Vanuatu includes 
addressing fundamental constraints to sustainable private sector-led economic growth, with a 
focus on increasing access to finance. The Government concurs with the TA's methodology, key 
activities,  implementation  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  A  memorandum  of 
understanding was signed by the Government, ADB, and the National Bank of Vanuatu (NBV) 
on 25 July 2007. The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  A major impediment to the development of local enterprises in Vanuatu is the restricted 
access to financial services, particularly in rural areas. ADB has previously provided assistance4 
to support sustainable microfinance activities through the government-owned NBV. The initial 
pilot TA was scaled up through the extension of banking services, including commercially-viable 
microfinance, through NBV branches on the outer islands. However, this expansion over the past 
4  years  can  no  longer  provide  cost-effective outreach.  To  serve  smaller  and  more  remote 
populations, new and innovative approaches are required. From previous TA, other lessons 
learned include the need to combine both policy and operational activities with NBV, and the 
need for flexibility in implementing the TA. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Vanuatu has experienced both rapid population growth and—until recently—a long period 
of sluggish economic growth. As a result, the current real per capita income is lower than it was 
20 years ago. Vanuatu is the third poorest country in the Pacific with a rising human poverty 
index of 24.7, ranking it 49th out of 102 developing countries and areas.5 It has a population of 
229,000, 76% of which live in rural areas. Currently, only 13% of the rural adult population have 
bank accounts, and an estimated 92,000 need financial services.6
 
4.  Without  access  to  secure  and  convenient  financial  services,  many  rural  households 
remain dependant on subsistence farming, limiting their participation in the formal economy and 
their ability to increase their contribution toward economic growth. For example, those in isolated 
and remote communities throughout the country’s outer islands, without bank accounts, may 
store money in unsecure locations. Also in remote areas, government workers and teachers, 
who  receive  salary  payments  into  their  bank  accounts,  often  must  make  expensive,  time-

consuming inter-island journeys to the nearest NBV bank branch to access their income. In 
addition, the provision of credit, if it exists at all, is mainly through commodity traders or local 
stores and largely outside the financial sector. Not surprisingly, levels of financial literacy in such 
areas remain low. 
 
5.  The two large international commercial banks in the country, ANZ and Westpac, focus 
almost exclusively on the two urban centers of Port Vila and Luganville, although ANZ has 
recently introduced a banking van to provide mobile banking services to rural areas on the main 
island of Efate. In addition, there are several microfinance providers, but their operations are 
largely  urban-based.  The  United  Nations  Development  Programme  supports  the  Vanuatu 
Women’s Development Scheme, a modified Grameen Bank replication targeted at low-income 
urban women. This scheme has been successful in developing micro-saving and micro-credit 
schemes, but is not financially sustainable and has yet to achieve a scale of operations that 
would enable it to function outside urban areas. The Melanesian Cooperative Savings and Loan 
Society also operates mainly in urban areas, targeting salaried workers.  
6.  Two new entities may impact rural banking in the medium term. First, a new commercial 
bank, BRED (Vanuatu), a subsidiary of the French bank La Bred Banque Populaire, is currently 
setting up operations that will most likely focus on Port Vila. Second, a 2006 act established the 
Vanuatu Agriculture Development Bank, but to date, the bank has not been funded or staffed, 
although steps to achieve these goals are expected within the next year. 
7.  Presently, NBV is the key provider of rural financial services. It is the only domestic-
owned bank in Vanuatu, except for the Agriculture Development Bank, which still at the concept 
stage. Although government-owned, NBV operates on a fully commercial basis with professional 
management brought in from overseas. Since the late 1990s, NBV has progressively achieved 
consistent profit growth, a sound financial structure, and a good quality loan portfolio. It has 
expanded to 21 branches throughout the country, and with support from previous ADB TAs, has 
developed a microfinance loan product with consistent high repayment rates, making a positive 
contribution to its profits. As of 30 June 2007, NBV’s microfinance loan portfolio was comprised 
of 542 loans, totaling Vt105 million ($1 million equivalent). Microfinance loans with arrears of 
more than 60 days were equivalent to only 0.6% of this portfolio. While the microfinance portfolio 
is small—equivalent to only 3% of NBV’s total loan portfolio—it is still larger than that of other 
microfinance  operations  within  the  country.  Deposits  mobilized  by  NBV  in  rural  areas  are 
approximately Vt540 million ($5.4 million equivalent). 
8.  NBV is committed to further expanding its services to isolated and remote communities 
throughout the country’s outer islands. However, the costs involved in setting up branches to 
serve smaller markets are prohibitive. Accordingly, NBV has been investigating the possibility of 
using alternative branchless business models to increase its outreach in a cost-effective and 
sustainable manner.   
9.  Recent international experience has demonstrated that new technologies and business 
models can provide opportunities for agent-assisted branchless banking to reach the poorest 
sectors of society. The proposed business model to be introduced by NBV—expanding outreach 
through bank agents equipped with new technology—has been applied in several countries. 
Brazil, for example, has 90,000 such bank agents. Over the past decade, experience in applying 
technology to microfinance operations has also been gained in Uganda and the Philippines. 
Although  there  is  experience  in  other  countries  with  branchless  banking,  there  are  no 
international examples that incorporate remote banking technologies and agent models with 
dispersed islands and remote populations. Customizing the mix of established technologies for 
Vanuatu  is  therefore  essential,  while  taking  into  account  the  local  telecommunication  and 
electricity infrastructure.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
10.  The TA will increase the availability and utilization of sustainable financial services to the 
rural population in order to boost its participation in income-generating activities that contribute to 
economic growth. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will support NBV by introducing a new business model of bank agents in rural 
communities beyond the reach of present NBV branches. Equipped with appropriate technology 
and communications equipment, these agents will enable much of the presently unbanked rural 
population to establish and operate savings accounts and utilize account transaction facilities 
conveniently.  
 
12.  In a typical example, a person living in a remote area opens an account and is issued an 
electronic funds transfer point of sale (eftPOS) card. The bank client then makes a deposit, 
withdrawal, or payment to another account by presenting the card to an agent—a local store 
owner—who swipes the card on an eftPOS device, which is connected via cell phone to the 
bank’s system by a special purpose router known as a switch. The bank’s system approves the 
transaction, and the agent exchanges any cash with the client and provides a record with a 
confirmation  code.  The  bank’s  system  then  adjusts  the  client’s  and  the  agent’s  accounts. 
Periodically, the agent travels to a bank branch to manage cash on hand with the agent. In a 
variation of this model, a client may use a cell phone to check account balances, make payments 
to other accounts, or receive confirmation of a deposit to an agent. 
 
13.  The regulatory framework for commercial banks authorizes the central bank, the Reserve 
Bank of Vanuatu (RBV), to supervise bank agents in their deposit-taking role. After consulting 
RBV, there are presently no legal or regulatory impediments to the bank agent model. Although 
RBV is supportive of the concept, NBV must ensure that appropriate systems and controls are 
instituted to meet ongoing supervisory requirements when instituting this model. 
 
14.  The telecommunications situation in Vanuatu is characterized by relatively low levels of 
access outside of the main population centers, and by high costs. Over time, unmet demand and 
an incumbent monopoly are likely to give way to a more competitive market and increased 
coverage.  Nevertheless,  remote  communications  will  remain  a  challenge,  and  the  available 
options must be carefully weighed for this project to succeed. Options include the fixed line 
network, (Global System for Mobile communications) (cellular), and VSAT (Very Small Aperture 
Terminal) and Iridium (satellite-based). The non-fixed line options may be more costly, but there 
are at least some telecommunication options available for the country’s most remote areas. 
 
15.  To mitigate the risks involved in introducing an innovative, branchless banking system, a 
four-phase program is planned for the TA. The TA will provide assistance to NBV during the first 
three phases over a period of 30 months. 
 
(i)  Phase I: Business development. Over 3 months, a detailed investigation and 
analysis  of  the  business  case  will  be  undertaken.  This will  include  a  market 
assessment; financial modeling; development of an agent business model; and a 
detailed  assessment  of  technology  options  covering  field  devices  for  agents, 
telecommunications links, and their integration into NBV’s core banking system.

4   
The cost of various telecommunication options is expected to be a key issue in 
the  evaluation  and  selection  of  technology.  Regulatory  issues  will  also  be 
addressed. This phase’s outcome will encompass decisions on the technology, 
evaluation, and selection of hardware and software providers, and finalization of 
pilot stage design. 
(ii)  Phase II: Technology implementation. This 3-month period will result in the 
delivery and integration of head office hardware and software, delivery of pilot 
field equipment such as eftPOS devices and cards, and completion of testing and 
validation of all field and head office equipment and systems.  
(iii)  Phase III: Pilot program. A 24-month pilot program will result in a target 12 
agents in operation. The agents’ selection and location will focus on testing the 
effectiveness  of  the  agent  model  under  a  variety  of  conditions,  e.g.,  various 
markets, customer education approaches, technology choices, types and quality 
of telecommunications, and electricity supply. The pilot experience will enable 
design of the final scale-up model. As part of the pilot program, NBV’s capacity to 
select and train agents will be developed, and a financial awareness and literacy 
program will be carried out in pilot areas. 
(iv)  Phase IV: Scale-up. Thanks to the pilot experience, several procedures and 
business operations will be formalized, e.g., procedures and operating manuals 
for agents; the basis for selection, training, remuneration, monitoring, and control 
of agents; and customer education and marketing programs. The scale-up and 
training of agents will occur progressively over several years, with potential for 
80–100  agents  in  operation  within  5  years,  providing  40%–50%  of  the  rural 
population with access to financial services.  
 
16.  There  is  confidence  that  workable  technology  solutions  will  be  available  for  NBV, 
notwithstanding the challenging status of the country’s infrastructure. Cost estimates will be 
explored in detail in phase I, with the cost of telephone calls for data communication between the 
agent eftPOS and NBV core banking system significantly impacting the model’s attractiveness to 
both agent and client. Thus, the rate of model’s adoption and progress are presently difficult to 
assess accurately. 
 
17.  In the next few years, there is limited potential for increased competition with NBV in the 
delivery of financial services to rural areas due to outreach costs. Contributing to increased 
financial literacy will also be an important part of the TA, including the concepts of borrowing and 
repayment, interest rates and cost recovery, and sustainable investing.  
 
18.  The TA will be closely coordinated with ADB’s ongoing TA in Vanuatu, particularly for 
secured transactions reform and support to the Financial Services Commission.7  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The  TA’s  total  cost  is  estimated  to  be  $750,000  equivalent,  with  the  Government 
requesting that ADB finance $600,000 equivalent. This TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. NBV will finance the balance of 
the  local  currency  cost,  equivalent  to  $150,000,  through  counterpart  staff  salaries,  office 
accommodation, and other support services. 
 
                                                 
7   ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Vanuatu for Financial Services Commission on Institutional

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economic  Management  (MFEM)  will  be  the  Executing 
Agency, and NBV will be the Implementing Agency. NBV will appoint a senior executive as 
project manager responsible for project development and implementation. The project manager 
will report directly to NBV‘s managing director, and will coordinate with its senior management 
team and the consultants. NBV will also provide office space and support services for the 
consultants. MFEM must supervise the TA’s implementation and ensure its effectiveness. MFEM 
and NBV will hold regular meetings to ensure that MFEM is kept informed and the project 
remains on target. 
 
21.  It is anticipated that a total 10 person-months in international consulting services will be 
required for the TA’s implementation. Due to the high level of NBV staff involvement in project 
management and implementation, there is no requirement for national consultants. 
 
22.  Beginning in March 2008, the TA will be implemented over a total of 30 months to 
September 2010, with intermittent inputs from three international consultants. The consultant 
team will be drawn from a firm with expertise in the development and application of technology in 
microfinance enterprises. The consulting team will be comprised of a microfinance development 
expert  (4  person-months),  a  microfinance  technology  expert  (4  person-months),  and  a 
microfinance education and training expert (2 person-months). The team of consultants will be 
selected  as  an  international  team  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). All equipment purchased under the TA, including eftPOS devices, cards, and associated 
software, will also be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The equipment will remain with NBV following the TA’s completion. Several 
workshops and seminars will be held under the TA to provide training for NBV staff and agents 
and  build  community  awareness  and  financial  literacy.  Administration  of  the  seminar  and 
workshop survey funds will occur under the international consulting firm contract. Consulting 
firms will be requested to submit simplified technical proposals. The ratio for the selection of the 
firm will be 80% quality and 20% cost. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Vanuatu for Expanding Access to Financial Services, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consulting Inputs 
1.  Consulting inputs will be sequenced over three phases that will precede the expected full 
scale-up of agent banking by the National Bank of Vanuatu (NBV). 
 
(i)  Phase I: Business Development (3 months), 
(ii)  Phase II: Technology Implementation (3 months), and 
(iii)  Phase III: Pilot Program (24 months).  
 
B.  Scope of Work 
1.  Microfinance Development Expert/Team Leader (international, 4  
person-months) 
2.  The  microfinance  development  expert  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  economics, 
business administration, law, information technology, or a similar field. The expert shall have at 
least 5 years’ experience in the design and implementation of microfinance projects including 
those involving agent networks. The expert  will have overall responsibility for coordinating 
consulting inputs with NBV and be an excellent communicator. Experience with Pacific islands 
or small states is an advantage.   
 
3.  The microfinance development expert will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  in rural areas of Vanuatu, assess the market for financial services using focus 
group  interviews  to  evaluate  potential  customers’  attitudes  toward  accessing 
banking services through NBV agents; and identify key market segments, sizes, 
the value of agent banking services, and customers’ ability and willingness to pay 
for services (phase I); 
(ii)  based on the market assessment and drawing on international best practices, 
develop  a  set  of  potential  bank  agent  business  models  for  NBV,  including 
consideration of agent incentive structures, fraud control, and cash management 
measures (phase I); 
(iii)  working  in  conjunction  with  NBV  and  the  microfinance  technology  expert, 
undertake a financial evaluation to assess and optimize the choice of technology 
and agent business models (phase I); 
(iv)  assess the legal and regulatory environment for agent banking, and support 
NBV’s ongoing dialogue with the Reserve Bank of Vanuatu (RBV) as the bank 
agent model is formulated (phase I, with ongoing support in phases II and III); 
(v)  drawing on international experience, prepare guidelines for consideration by RBV 
for regulatory general oversight of bank agents (phase I); 
(vi)  with  NBV,  undertake  pilot  project  design,  including  the  development  of  a 
monitoring and evaluation process for the pilot (phase I);  
(vii)  assist NBV in the roll-out of the pilot program (phase III); 
(viii)  prepare draft operating manuals for NBV agents and staff for roll-out of the pilot 
program (phase III);  
(ix)  review and refine operating manuals for NBV agents and staff based on the pilot 
program’s lessons learned (phase III);

(x)  undertake overall evaluation of the pilot program, identifying lessons learned and 
developing refinements and recommendations for implementation of the scale-up 
phase (phase III); and 
(xi)  prepare and submit inception, progress, and final reports; effectively lead the 
consultant team; and take overall responsibility for and ownership of the delivery 
of expected technical assistance (TA) outputs and outcomes (all phases). 
 
2.  Microfinance Technology Expert (international, 4 person-months) 
4.  The microfinance technology expert will have a master’s degree in economics, business 
administration, law, information technology, engineering, or a similar field. The expert will have 
at least 5 years’ experience in information technology project management, preferably in a bank 
or microfinance institution involving roll-out programs for point-of-sale devices. The expert will 
be an excellent communicator.  
 
5.  The microfinance technology expert will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  assess  the  status  of,  and  trends  in,  availability  of  telecommunication  and 
electricity infrastructure in Vanuatu, particularly in rural areas (phase I); 
(ii)  taking into account the core banking system utilized by NBV, identify the range of 
potential technology solutions that may be used to support the introduction of 
agent banking by NBV (phase I); 
(iii)  support  NBV  in  identifying  and  evaluating  technology  vendors  through 
developing  use  cases/requirements,  including  process  mapping;  undertaking 
simple  gap  analysis  between  existing  and  future  software  requirements; 
preparing  terms  of  reference  and  requests  for  proposals  from  vendors;  and 
evaluating vendor proposals (phase I); 
(iv)  in  conjunction  with  the  financial  evaluation  undertaken  by  the  microfinance 
development  expert,  support  NBV  in  determining  the  optimal  choice  of 
technology and agent business models (phase I); 
(v)  support  NBV  to  undertake  project  management  for  implementation  of  the 
technology  infrastructure,  covering  the  procurement  of  necessary  supplier 
licenses and hardware, as well as overseeing integration activities and testing 
and validating the system (phase II); 
(vi)  support  technology  implementation  and  refinement  during  the  pilot  program, 
including technological maintenance activities, ongoing licensing, ongoing card 
purchases, and monitoring and evaluation of the technology systems (phase III); 
and 
(vii)  evaluate the technology aspects of the pilot program to identify lessons learned 
and refinements recommended for implementation in the scale-up phase (phase 
III). 
 
3.  Microfinance Education and Training Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
6.  The microfinance education and training expert will have a master’s degree in education, 
economics, business administration, law, information technology, or a similar field. The expert 
will have at least 5 years’ relevant professional experience in conducting microfinance-related 
training and education.  
 
7.   The microfinance education and training expert will undertake the following tasks:

up phase (phase III). 
 
C.  Reporting 
 
8.  Beginning in March 2008, the TA will be implemented over 30 months until September 
2010, with intermittent inputs from the international consultants.  
 
9.  The team leader will submit an inception report, including a detailed work plan and 
conceptual issues relevant to project delivery, 6 weeks after the TA’s commencement. Progress 
reports will be submitted at the conclusion of phase I, 3 months after TA commencement; at the 
conclusion of phase II, 6 months after TA commencement; and every 3 months thereafter. The 
initial progress report will include guidelines for consideration by RBV for regulatory general 
oversight of bank agents. A comprehensive draft final report will be submitted at least 6 weeks 
prior to the final tripartite meeting. A final report will be submitted 4 weeks after receipt of 
comments by Asian Development Bank, NBV, and Government counterparts.
